title: Automatic weapons (Uzi, AK47) don't support hold-to-fire
description:
## Summary
When using automatic weapons like Uzi or AK47:
- Player must repeatedly click to fire each shot
- Cannot hold down mouse button for continuous fire
- This makes automatic weapons feel like semi-automatic and reduces fun factor

Expected behavior: Hold mouse button down ‚Üí weapon fires continuously at its fire rate

## Root Cause Analysis
Looking at `GameScene.ts:149-155`:
```typescript
this.input.on('pointerdown', () => {
  if (this.shootingManager && this.inputManager) {
    this.shootingManager.setAimAngle(this.inputManager.getAimAngle());
    this.shootingManager.shoot();
  }
});
```

The shooting only triggers on `pointerdown` event (single click), not on held pointer.

Need to:
1. Track if pointer is held down
2. In update loop, check if pointer is held and weapon is automatic
3. Continuously call shoot() while held (respecting fire rate cooldown)

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Holding mouse button fires Uzi continuously at 6 rounds/sec
- [ ] Holding mouse button fires AK47 continuously at 5 rounds/sec
- [ ] Pistol still requires individual clicks (semi-automatic)
- [ ] Shotgun still requires individual clicks (pump action)
- [ ] Fire rate cooldown still enforced (no faster than weapon allows)
- [ ] Tests verify automatic fire behavior

## Technical Notes
Files to modify:
- `stick-rumble-client/src/game/scenes/GameScene.ts` - add pointerup tracking and update loop logic
- `stick-rumble-client/src/game/input/ShootingManager.ts` - add isAutomatic check based on weapon type

Weapon fire rates (from server):
- Uzi: 6.0 rounds/sec
- AK47: 5.0 rounds/sec  
- Pistol: 3.0 rounds/sec (semi-auto)
- Shotgun: 1.0 rounds/sec (pump)

title: Player characters duplicate and errors flood console when match restarts
description:
## Summary
When a match ends and the game restarts:
1. Player characters appear duplicated on screen (multiple sprites per player)
2. Console floods with errors: 'TypeError: Cannot read properties of null'
3. Errors occur in PlayerManager.updatePlayers() - trying to read 'add' on null
4. Errors occur in GameSceneUI.updateMatchTimer() - trying to read 'drawImage' on null

From screenshot: Multiple red/green player rectangles visible, console shows repeated errors at:
- PlayerManager.ts:115:33 (reading 'add')
- PlayerManager.ts:182:27 (reading 'setTo')
- GameSceneUI.ts:254:25 (reading 'drawImage')

## Root Cause Analysis
Research document at `research/2025-12-08-player-duplication-bug.md` analyzed this:

1. **No proper match restart mechanism** - Match ends but no clean restart path exists
2. **Sprites not cleaned up** - PlayerManager.destroy() exists but may not be called correctly
3. **Handler accumulation** - Event handlers may be re-registered without cleanup
4. **Null reference errors** - Graphics objects destroyed but still being updated

The `room:joined` handler does call `playerManager.destroy()` (line 186 in GameSceneEventHandlers.ts) but something is causing duplication anyway.

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] After match ends, clicking 'Play Again' starts fresh match without duplicates
- [ ] No console errors related to null references
- [ ] Player sprites properly cleaned up between matches
- [ ] All event handlers properly unregistered and re-registered
- [ ] Works correctly for multiple consecutive matches

## Technical Notes
Files to investigate:
- `stick-rumble-client/src/game/scenes/GameScene.ts` - cleanup() and restartMatch()
- `stick-rumble-client/src/game/scenes/GameSceneEventHandlers.ts` - handler cleanup
- `stick-rumble-client/src/game/entities/PlayerManager.ts` - destroy() method
- `stick-rumble-client/src/ui/common/PhaserGame.tsx` - game lifecycle
- `stick-rumble-server/internal/game/room.go` - match restart on server

title: Melee weapons show 0/0 ammo and RELOAD indicator - weapons broken
description:
## Summary
When picking up melee weapons (Bat or Katana), the UI incorrectly shows:
- Ammo display: 0/0 (should be hidden or show infinite for melee)
- RELOAD! indicator flashes (melee weapons don't reload)
- Melee attacks do not work at all

## Root Cause Analysis
Looking at the code:
1. `ShootingManager.ts` handles both ranged and melee weapons
2. When weapon state updates (`weapon:state` message), it sets `currentAmmo` and `maxAmmo`
3. For melee weapons, server sends `magazineSize: 0` (see `weapon.go:96`: `CurrentAmmo: weapon.MagazineSize`)
4. `GameSceneUI.updateAmmoDisplay()` shows RELOAD! when `isEmpty()` returns true (ammo <= 0)

The client needs to:
1. Hide ammo display for melee weapons
2. Not show RELOAD indicator for melee
3. Call `meleeAttack()` instead of `shoot()` for melee weapons on click

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Picking up Bat or Katana hides the ammo counter
- [ ] No RELOAD indicator shown for melee weapons  
- [ ] Click triggers melee attack for melee weapons (not ranged shoot)
- [ ] Melee attacks register hits on server
- [ ] Tests cover melee weapon UI behavior

## Technical Notes
Files to modify:
- `stick-rumble-client/src/game/scenes/GameSceneUI.ts` - hide ammo for melee
- `stick-rumble-client/src/game/scenes/GameScene.ts` - call meleeAttack() for melee  
- `stick-rumble-client/src/game/input/ShootingManager.ts` - track weapon type for attack routing
- `stick-rumble-client/src/game/scenes/GameSceneEventHandlers.ts` - update weapon type tracking

title: Automatic weapons (Uzi, AK47) lack distinct firing patterns and visual character
description:
## Problem
The Uzi and AK47 have identical firing patterns that are indistinguishable from the pistol. While damage values are correct and screen shake works, the weapons lack distinct visual and behavioral characteristics.

## Current Behavior
- All guns fire with the same visual pattern
- Bullets look and behave identically across weapon types
- No perceptible difference in fire rate visuals, muzzle flash, or projectile appearance
- Weapons don't feel distinct despite having different stats

## Expected Behavior
Each weapon should have unique characteristics:

**Pistol**: Single, precise shots with deliberate pacing
**Uzi**: Rapid-fire spray with visible spread, faster but less accurate
**AK47**: Powerful bursts with heavier recoil feel, slower than Uzi but more impactful

## Suggested Improvements
- Different projectile speeds/sizes per weapon
- Distinct muzzle flash effects (size, color, duration)
- Weapon-specific spread patterns
- Different firing sound cadences (if audio exists)
- Tracer/bullet trail variations

## Related
- stick-rumble-0hv: Automatic weapons don't support hold-to-fire (separate issue)

title: Tech Debt: Split epics.md into separate epic documents
description:
The current epics.md file is too large (~31K tokens) and overwhelms agent context windows when read.

**Problem:**
- docs/epics.md contains all epics (1-9+) in a single file
- File exceeds 25K token read limit, requiring offset/limit pagination
- Agents waste context loading irrelevant epic content
- Difficult to maintain and update individual epics

**Acceptance Criteria:**

1. Split epics.md into individual epic files:
   - docs/epics/epic-1-multiplayer-foundation.md
   - docs/epics/epic-2-core-combat.md
   - docs/epics/epic-3-weapon-systems.md
   - docs/epics/epic-4-networked-gameplay.md
   - (continue for epics 5-9)

2. Create docs/epics/README.md or docs/epics/index.md:
   - Overview of all epics with status
   - Links to individual epic files
   - Quick reference for epic dependencies

3. Keep docs/epics.md as redirect/deprecated notice:
   - Point to new location
   - Or delete entirely after migration

4. Update any references to epics.md in codebase:
   - CLAUDE.md if applicable
   - Any other documentation

**Expected Result:**
- Each epic file ~2-4K tokens (easily fits in context)
- Agents can read only the relevant epic
- Easier to update progress per-epic
- Better git history (changes isolated to specific epics)

**Technical Notes:**
- Current file has 1198+ lines
- Epic 3 alone spans lines 721-1152 (~430 lines)
- Consider using consistent frontmatter (status, progress, dates)

title: Part 2: Playwright Visual Tests for Game Entities + CI Integration
description:
## Summary
This is Part 2 of the comprehensive test harness (stick-rumble-q26 was Part 1). Part 1 added enhanced Phaser mocks and scene lifecycle unit tests. Part 2 adds Playwright visual tests that run in the actual browser to catch rendering bugs that unit tests cannot detect.

## Why This Matters
Even with excellent unit test coverage (90%+), bugs like player sprite duplication (AT3) and melee animation not rendering (o5y) slip through because:
1. Unit tests verify method calls, not actual pixels on screen
2. Unit tests use mocks, not real Phaser rendering
3. Visual bugs only manifest in the actual browser

## Relationship to AT3 (Player Sprite Duplication Bug)
The AT3 bug is a perfect example of what Part 2 will catch:
- PR #39 claimed to fix sprite duplication but it still occurs
- Unit tests pass but browser shows duplicate sprites
- A Playwright visual test for `restartScene()` would catch this immediately
- The test harness will expose `getActiveSprites()` to verify sprite count = player count

## Acceptance Criteria

### Phase 1: Test Harness HTML Page
- [ ] Create `/public/ui-test-entities.html` following the existing `/ui-test.html` pattern
- [ ] Create `src/entity-test-scene.ts` for isolated entity testing
- [ ] Expose window functions:
  - `window.spawnPlayer(id, x, y, color)` - Create a player sprite
  - `window.removePlayer(id)` - Remove a player sprite
  - `window.getPlayerCount()` - Return count of active player sprites
  - `window.getActiveSprites()` - Return array of all active sprites
  - `window.triggerMeleeSwing(weaponType, angle)` - Trigger melee animation
  - `window.restartScene()` - Restart the scene (simulates match restart)
  - `window.clearAllSprites()` - Clean slate for tests
- [ ] Initialize with dark background for visual contrast in screenshots

### Phase 2: Playwright Visual Tests
- [ ] Create `tests/visual/player-sprites.spec.ts`:
  - Test single player spawn renders correctly
  - Test multiple players spawn without overlap
  - Test player removal cleans up sprite completely
  - **CRITICAL**: Test scene restart does NOT duplicate sprites (catches AT3 bug)
  - Test `getActiveSprites().length === expected` after each operation
- [ ] Create `tests/visual/melee-animation.spec.ts`:
  - Test Bat swing shows brown arc (0x8B4513)
  - Test Katana swing shows silver arc (0xC0C0C0)
  - Test arc is visible during animation
  - Test arc is NOT visible after animation completes
- [ ] Create `tests/visual/scene-lifecycle.spec.ts`:
  - Test fresh scene has zero sprites
  - Test spawn/remove cycle leaves zero sprites
  - Test multiple restarts do not accumulate zombie sprites

### Phase 3: CI Integration
- [ ] Update `vitest.config.ts` to NOT exclude visual tests from main test run
- [ ] Add Playwright visual test step to CI workflow
- [ ] Configure screenshot diff reporting on test failure
- [ ] Failed visual tests should block PR merge

## Technical Notes

### Existing Pattern to Follow
```typescript
// tests/visual/health-bar.spec.ts - 105 lines
// Uses custom page /ui-test.html with exposed global functions
await page.evaluate(() => {
  (window as any).setHealthBarState(100, 100, false);
});
await expect(page.locator(".health-bar")).toHaveScreenshot();
```

### Entity Test Harness Architecture
```
public/ui-test-entities.html
  ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ Loads entity-test-scene.ts
      ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ Creates Phaser game with EntityTestScene
          ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ EntityTestScene.create() exposes window.* functions
          ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ Uses real PlayerManager, MeleeWeapon, etc.
```

### AT3 Bug Detection Test
```typescript
// This test would catch the AT3 bug
it("should not duplicate sprites after scene restart", async ({ page }) => {
  await page.goto("/ui-test-entities.html");
  
  // Spawn a player
  await page.evaluate(() => window.spawnPlayer("p1", 100, 100, "red"));
  expect(await page.evaluate(() => window.getActiveSprites().length)).toBe(1);
  
  // Restart scene (this is where AT3 bug causes duplication)
  await page.evaluate(() => window.restartScene());
  
  // Spawn same player again
  await page.evaluate(() => window.spawnPlayer("p1", 100, 100, "red"));
  
  // Should still be 1, not 2 (AT3 bug would show 2)
  expect(await page.evaluate(() => window.getActiveSprites().length)).toBe(1);
  
  // Visual confirmation - screenshot should show 1 player, not 2
  await expect(page.locator("canvas")).toHaveScreenshot();
});
```

### Files to Create
- `stick-rumble-client/public/ui-test-entities.html` - Test harness HTML
- `stick-rumble-client/src/entity-test-scene.ts` - Entity test scene
- `stick-rumble-client/tests/visual/player-sprites.spec.ts` - Player visual tests
- `stick-rumble-client/tests/visual/melee-animation.spec.ts` - Melee visual tests
- `stick-rumble-client/tests/visual/scene-lifecycle.spec.ts` - Lifecycle visual tests

### Files to Modify
- `stick-rumble-client/vitest.config.ts` - Include visual tests
- `.github/workflows/*` - Add visual test step (if CI workflow exists)

## Success Metrics
- Visual tests catch sprite duplication before human playtesting
- AT3 bug would fail the `player-sprites.spec.ts` scene restart test
- Melee animation bugs would fail the `melee-animation.spec.ts` visibility test
- No more "fix merged but bug still exists" scenarios

## Related Issues
- stick-rumble-q26: Part 1 (COMPLETED - PR #44)
- stick-rumble-at3: Player sprite duplication (will be caught by this work)
- stick-rumble-o5y: Melee animation not working (will be caught by this work)
- stick-rumble-nxt: GameScene coverage gaps (separate infrastructure issue)
notes:
## CRITICAL: Snapshots Must Be Committed

Visual regression tests require baseline snapshots to be committed to the repo. The worker initially gitignored tests/screenshots/ which defeats the entire purpose.

FIX APPLIED: Removed gitignore rule, committed 27 baseline snapshots:
- melee-animation: 10 snapshots
- player-sprites: 5 snapshots  
- projectile-visuals: 5 snapshots
- scene-lifecycle: 7 snapshots

LESSON FOR FUTURE WORKERS: Never gitignore visual test snapshots - they ARE the test.

title: Story 3.6: Implement Dodge Roll with Invincibility Frames
description:
Implement dodge roll with invincibility frames for skillful evasion.

**SCOPE: Full-stack implementation (client + server)**

**Acceptance Criteria:**

1. **Dodge Activation (Space bar):**
   - Press Space to roll in current movement direction
   - If stationary, roll in aim direction (forward)
   - Roll direction based on WASD keys pressed

2. **Roll Stats:**
   - Duration: 0.4 seconds total
   - Distance: 100 pixels covered
   - Velocity: 250 px/s for 0.4 seconds
   - Cooldown: 3 seconds between rolls

3. **Invincibility Frames:**
   - First 0.2s: INVINCIBLE (cannot take damage)
   - Last 0.2s: VULNERABLE to damage
   - Server check: if (isRolling && now - rollStartTime < 200) { ignoreDamage }

4. **Action Restrictions During Roll:**
   - Cannot shoot during roll
   - Cannot reload during roll
   - Cannot switch weapons during roll

5. **Collision:**
   - Roll cancels if hitting wall/obstacle
   - Roll stopped immediately on collision

**SERVER Requirements:**
- Track roll state: {isRolling: bool, rollStartTime: timestamp, lastRollTime: timestamp}
- Roll stats: {duration: 0.4s, distance: 100px, iframes: 0.2s, cooldown: 3s}
- Invincibility frame validation: ignore damage during first 0.2s
- Cooldown enforcement (prevent spam)
- Block actions during roll (shoot, reload, weapon switch)
- Wall collision detection to cancel roll
- WebSocket messages: roll:start, roll:end

**CLIENT Requirements:**
- Space bar input handling for dodge roll
- 6-frame roll animation, sprite rotates 360¬∞
- Transparency/ghost effect during i-frames (first 0.2s)
- Cooldown UI: circular timer shows when dodge available
- "Whoosh" sound effect on roll
- Block input during roll (visual feedback, server validates)
- Roll direction indicator based on WASD keys
- WebSocket integration for roll state sync
- Unit tests for client-side roll code (>90% coverage)

**Technical Notes:**
- Server is authoritative for roll state and i-frames
- Roll stats: {duration: 0.4s, distance: 100px, iframes: 0.2s, cooldown: 3s}
- Cooldown enforcement: client shows UI, server validates (prevent spam)

**Prerequisites:** Story 3.5 (Sprint Mechanic)

title: Leaderboard shows 0 kills/deaths: GetFinalScores uses wrong data source
description:
## Problem
Match end leaderboard shows 0 kills and 0 deaths for all players even when players got kills during the match. This is a regression or incomplete fix from stick-rumble-ife.

## Root Cause Analysis
`GetFinalScores()` in `match.go:186-213` has a data source mismatch:

```go
for playerID := range m.PlayerKills {      // Uses Match.PlayerKills for iteration
    player, exists := world.players[playerID]
    score := PlayerScore{
        Kills:  player.Kills,               // But reads from PlayerState.Kills
        Deaths: player.Deaths,              // And PlayerState.Deaths  
    }
}
```

There are TWO separate kill tracking systems:
1. `Match.PlayerKills` - incremented by `room.Match.AddKill()` in message_processor.go:233
2. `PlayerState.Kills` - incremented by `attackerState.IncrementKills()` in message_processor.go:171

The code iterates over players who have Match kills, but reads the kill count from PlayerState - these can get out of sync if:
- PlayerState is reset on respawn/reconnect
- World players are cleared before GetFinalScores is called
- Race condition between the two tracking systems

## Evidence
- Screenshot shows both players with 0 kills, 0 deaths
- XP breakdown shows 'Kills (0 √ó 100): 0'
- Server logs show match ended but no kill events visible

## Fix Options

### Option A: Use Match.PlayerKills directly (preferred)
```go
score := PlayerScore{
    Kills:  m.PlayerKills[playerID],  // Use match's kill tracking
    Deaths: m.PlayerDeaths[playerID], // Need to add death tracking to Match
}
```

### Option B: Remove duplicate tracking
Only use PlayerState for kills/deaths, iterate over world.players instead of m.PlayerKills

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Kills display correctly in match end leaderboard
- [ ] Deaths display correctly in match end leaderboard
- [ ] XP calculation uses correct kill count
- [ ] Add logging to verify data flow during match end
- [ ] Integration test that verifies kills persist through match lifecycle

## Related Issues
- stick-rumble-ife: Original schema fix (closed but incomplete)
- stick-rumble-wzq: Testing improvements to catch config sync issues - **similar pattern of dual data sources**

## Testing Improvements Needed
This is the SAME bug pattern as stick-rumble-wzq (weapon-configs.json vs hardcoded fallback):
1. **Dual source of truth** - two places tracking the same data
2. **No integration test** verifying end-to-end data flow
3. **Unit tests pass** but don't test the integration point

Recommended tests:
1. E2E test: Player kills ‚Üí match end ‚Üí leaderboard shows correct kills
2. Integration test: Verify Match.PlayerKills == PlayerState.Kills after kill
3. Component test: Mock GetFinalScores output and verify MatchEndScreen renders correctly
notes:
## Pattern Analysis

This bug is part of a recurring pattern across the codebase:

### Pattern: Dual Source of Truth
Three open issues share this exact pattern:
- **6s2** (this): Match.PlayerKills vs PlayerState.Kills/Deaths
- **wzq**: weapon-configs.json vs hardcoded WeaponConfig
- **njr**: Client hardcoded fire rate vs server weapon config

### Why Unit Tests Missed This
- GetFinalScores() unit tests manually set both Match.PlayerKills AND PlayerState.Kills
- Real runtime only calls Match.AddKill() in one place, PlayerState.IncrementKills() in another
- No integration test verifies they stay in sync during actual gameplay

### Recommended Fix
Option A (preferred): Use Match tracking only
- Match.PlayerKills already tracks kills per player
- Add Match.PlayerDeaths map
- GetFinalScores reads from Match, not PlayerState
- Single source of truth

Option B: Use PlayerState only
- Remove Match.PlayerKills entirely
- Iterate over world.players in GetFinalScores
- Register all players in match at start (not just on kill)

### Testing Needed
- Integration test: player kills enemy -> match ends -> verify finalScores.kills > 0
- Parity test: after each kill, assert Match.PlayerKills[id] == PlayerState.Kills

### Related Issues  
- stick-rumble-wzq: Same dual-source pattern (weapon configs)
- stick-rumble-njr: Same pattern (fire rate config)
- stick-rumble-48z: Visual tests could verify leaderboard renders correctly

title: Refactor network package tests for better quality and maintainability

3. Remove duplicate tests, keep best version of each
4. Update integration tests to read and validate WebSocket messages
5. Replace time.Sleep with proper synchronization primitives

- More maintainable test suite

- Easier to understand what each test validates
- Reduces test execution time

title: Story 3.4: Implement Manual Reload Mechanic
description:
Implement manual reload mechanic for tactical ammo management.

**SCOPE: Full-stack implementation (client + server)**

**Acceptance Criteria:**

1. **Manual Reload (R key):**
   - Press R to start reload animation
   - During reload: cannot shoot (clicking does nothing)
   - Reload progress bar appears on HUD (fills over reload duration)
   - After completion: magazine refills to max capacity

2. **Reload Times Per Weapon:**
   - Uzi: 1.5 seconds
   - AK47: 2.0 seconds
   - Shotgun: 2.5 seconds

3. **Cancel & Auto-Reload:**
   - Cancel reload by switching weapons (lose progress)
   - Auto-reload triggers when shooting with empty magazine
   - Empty indicator: "RELOAD!" flashes on screen in red

4. **Movement During Reload:**
   - Can move, sprint, and dodge while reloading (not stunned)
   - Reload does NOT cancel on movement

**SERVER Requirements:**
- Track reload state: {isReloading: bool, reloadStartTime: timestamp}
- Reload progress calculation: (now - reloadStartTime) / reloadDuration
- Validate reload completion before allowing shots
- Handle cancel triggers: weapon switch, weapon pickup
- Auto-reload trigger: attempt to shoot with ammo === 0
- WebSocket messages: reload:start, reload:complete, reload:cancel

**CLIENT Requirements:**
- R key input handling to trigger reload
- Reload progress bar UI on HUD (fills over reload duration)
- "RELOAD!" flashing red indicator when magazine empty
- Circular reload indicator around crosshair
- Reload sound effects (unique per weapon type)
- Character animation: lowers weapon, reload gesture, raises weapon
- Block shoot input during reload (visual feedback only, server validates)
- WebSocket integration for reload state sync
- Unit tests for client-side reload code (>90% coverage)

**Technical Notes:**
- Server is authoritative for reload state
- Client shows progress based on server timestamps
- Cancel triggers: weapon switch, weapon pickup
- Auto-reload trigger: attempt to shoot with ammo === 0

title: Story 3.3: Implement Ranged Weapons (Uzi, AK47, Shotgun)
description:
Implement three ranged weapons with distinct characteristics for varied playstyles.

**SCOPE: Full-stack implementation (client + server)**

**Acceptance Criteria:**

1. **Uzi (SMG):**
   - 8 damage per bullet, 10 rounds/second (full-auto, hold to fire)
   - 600px max range, 30-round magazine, 1.5s reload
   - Recoil: aim angle climbs 2¬∞ per shot, recovers over 0.5s
   - Spread: +/-5¬∞ while moving

2. **AK47 (Rifle):**
   - 20 damage per bullet, 6 rounds/second (semi-auto, hold for continuous)
   - 800px max range, 30-round magazine, 2.0s reload
   - Balanced recoil: horizontal + vertical, +/-3¬∞ pattern
   - Accurate while stationary, spread while moving

3. **Shotgun:**
   - 8 pellets per shot, 7.5 damage each (60 total if all hit)
   - 300px max range, 15¬∞ cone spread
   - 1 shot/second, 6-round magazine, 2.5s reload
   - Devastating close range, weak at distance (spread too wide)

4. **CRITICAL - Damage Falloff (all ranged weapons):**
   ```
   if (distance > maxRange * 0.5) {
     damageFalloff = 1.0 - ((distance - maxRange * 0.5) / (maxRange * 0.5))
     actualDamage = baseDamage * damageFalloff
   }
   ```
   Example: AK47 at 400px = 20 dmg, 600px = 10 dmg, 800px = 0 dmg

**SERVER Requirements:**
- Weapon stats validation and storage
- Uzi: {damage: 8, fireRate: 10/s, mag: 30, reload: 1.5s, range: 600px, DPS: 80}
- AK47: {damage: 20, fireRate: 6/s, mag: 30, reload: 2.0s, range: 800px, DPS: 120}
- Shotgun: {damage: 60, fireRate: 1/s, mag: 6, reload: 2.5s, range: 300px, DPS: 60}
- Fire rate validation to prevent macros/exploits
- Damage falloff calculation
- Recoil patterns stored as {x, y} offset arrays per weapon
- Projectile spawning with weapon-specific properties

**CLIENT Requirements:**
- Weapon entities in src/game/entities/ for each weapon type
- Muzzle flash effects on fire
- Recoil visual feedback (screen shake, crosshair movement)
- Spread indicator on crosshair while moving
- Weapon-specific firing sounds
- Projectile rendering with weapon-specific visuals
- Input handling for full-auto (hold) vs semi-auto
- WebSocket integration for shoot input and hit results
- Unit tests for client-side weapon code (>90% coverage)

**Balance Warning:** AK47 is overpowered (highest DPS 120, longest range 800px, largest mag). Damage falloff is PRIMARY balance mechanism. If still dominant after implementation, reduce fire rate 6/s ‚Üí 5/s (DPS 100). See docs/weapon-balance-analysis.md.

**Prerequisites:** Story 3.1 (Weapon Pickup System)

title: Automatic weapons (Uzi, AK47) don't support hold-to-fire
description:
## Summary
When using automatic weapons like Uzi or AK47:
- Player must repeatedly click to fire each shot
- Cannot hold down mouse button for continuous fire
- This makes automatic weapons feel like semi-automatic and reduces fun factor

Expected behavior: Hold mouse button down ‚Üí weapon fires continuously at its fire rate

## Root Cause Analysis
Looking at `GameScene.ts:149-155`:
```typescript
this.input.on('pointerdown', () => {
  if (this.shootingManager && this.inputManager) {
    this.shootingManager.setAimAngle(this.inputManager.getAimAngle());
    this.shootingManager.shoot();
  }
});
```

The shooting only triggers on `pointerdown` event (single click), not on held pointer.

Need to:
1. Track if pointer is held down
2. In update loop, check if pointer is held and weapon is automatic
3. Continuously call shoot() while held (respecting fire rate cooldown)

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Holding mouse button fires Uzi continuously at 6 rounds/sec
- [ ] Holding mouse button fires AK47 continuously at 5 rounds/sec
- [ ] Pistol still requires individual clicks (semi-automatic)
- [ ] Shotgun still requires individual clicks (pump action)
- [ ] Fire rate cooldown still enforced (no faster than weapon allows)
- [ ] Tests verify automatic fire behavior

## Technical Notes
Files to modify:
- `stick-rumble-client/src/game/scenes/GameScene.ts` - add pointerup tracking and update loop logic
- `stick-rumble-client/src/game/input/ShootingManager.ts` - add isAutomatic check based on weapon type

- Issue persists after fresh clean build and browser refresh
- Original issue ela was closed but bug is NOT fixed

PR #39 / Commit 465eb49: 'fix: Implement match restart to prevent player sprite duplication'
- Added window.restartGame function
- Added scene restart mechanism
- Added cleanup in PhaserGame.tsx
- Tests pass but actual bug still occurs

## Root Cause Investigation Needed
1. Check if PlayerManager.destroy() is actually being called
2. Verify sprites are being removed from scene
3. Check for duplicate player:move handler registrations
4. Look for race conditions in player creation
5. Check if issue happens on initial join OR only after reconnect/restart

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] No duplicate player sprites appear on screen
- [ ] No duplicate 'Player' labels visible
- [ ] Works on initial connection
- [ ] Works after match restart
- [ ] Works after browser refresh
- [ ] Console shows no null reference errors

## Technical Notes
- Previous fix focused on match restart flow
- Bug may be in initial player creation, not just restart
- PlayerManager.ts handles sprite creation
- GameSceneEventHandlers.ts handles player:move events

## Related Issues
- stick-rumble-ela: Original bug (incorrectly closed)
- stick-rumble-o5y: Melee animation also not working (pattern of broken merges)
notes:
## Pattern: PR Merged But Bug Still Exists

This is part of a pattern across the codebase where:
1. PR claims to fix issue
2. Unit tests pass
3. Bug still exists in browser

### Other Issues With Same Pattern
- **o5y**: Melee animation PR merged, animation doesn't work
- **wzq**: Projectile visuals PR merged, all projectiles still yellow
- **6s2**: Schema fix PR merged, leaderboard still shows 0

### Root Cause
Unit tests verify method calls, not actual rendering. Need visual tests (48z) to catch these.

3. Fix the bug
4. Visual test now passes and prevents regression

4. Errors occur in GameSceneUI.updateMatchTimer() - trying to read 'drawImage' on null

- GameSceneUI.ts:254:25 (reading 'drawImage')

3. **Handler accumulation** - Event handlers may be re-registered without cleanup

title: Fix failing broadcast tests exposed by game server initialization
description:
After starting the game server in tests (stick-rumble-72z), several broadcast tests are now failing due to race conditions and timing issues:

FAILING TESTS:
- TestBroadcastProjectileSpawn: projectileId field is nil
- TestBroadcastPlayerDamaged: playerId nil, health not reduced  
- TestBroadcastPlayerDeath: message not received within 2s timeout
- TestBroadcastKillCredit: message not received within 2s timeout
- TestBroadcastWeaponPickup: respawnTime field nil
- TestBroadcastMatchTimer: assertion failure

ROOT CAUSE:
Tests call handler methods directly (ts.handler.onHit, ts.handler.sendWeaponState, etc.) to trigger message broadcasts. However, connections close (via defer conn.Close()) before the game server's broadcast loop can send the messages. This creates race conditions.

RECOMMENDED FIX:
1. Add small delays (100-200ms) after triggering events to allow broadcast loop to send messages
2. OR modify tests to trigger events through normal game flow (input messages) instead of direct handler calls
3. Ensure connections stay open long enough to receive all expected messages

These are test quality issues, not production bugs. The game server works correctly - the tests just need better synchronization.
close_reason: Fixed in PR #24 - Broadcast tests refactored with proper synchronization, all tests now pass

title: Fix intermittent test failures in network package (race condition)
close_reason: PR #17 merged - Race condition in network package tests fixed

comments.author: mtomcal
comments.text: Race condition identified: Multiple tests calling NewWebSocketHandler() causes concurrent schema loading with excessive logging. Every test loads 41 schemas (7 client-to-server + 34 server-to-client) independently. When tests run in parallel, this creates log spam and race conditions. Solution: Implement singleton pattern for SchemaLoader using sync.Once to ensure schemas load only once per test run.

comments.author: mtomcal
comments.text:
=== PHASE 1: Investigation Complete ===

Current state:
- Schema loader singleton pattern already implemented with sync.Once
- GetClientToServerSchemaLoader() and GetServerToClientSchemaLoader() use sync.Once 
- resetSchemaLoaderSingletons() exists for testing
- Global handler (globalHandler) created at package init time (line 97)

Race condition analysis:
1. Multiple tests create handlers via NewWebSocketHandler() or use global HandleWebSocket
2. Each handler creation calls Get*SchemaLoader() which loads schemas once
3. The singleton pattern prevents duplicate loading BUT the global handler loads schemas at package init
4. When tests run in parallel with -race, there may be contention on schema loading logs
5. The global handler shares state across tests using HandleWebSocket directly

Key issues identified:
- Global handler (line 97) creates singleton loaders at package initialization
- Some tests use globalHandler (via HandleWebSocket function), others create new handlers
- Tests don't consistently reset singletons between runs
- Potential log interleaving during parallel test execution

=== PHASE 2: Implementation Plan ===

Plan:
1. Add TestMain to reset singletons before each test package run

title: Story 3.7B: Health Bars & Hit Effects
description:
Implement health bars and hit effects for clear visual combat feedback.

**Acceptance Criteria:**

1. **Health Bar UI:**
   - Green bar (health), gray background, 32x4 pixels
   - Positioned 8 pixels above player head
   - Updates in real-time as health changes
   - Scales proportionally from 0-100 HP

2. **Hit Effects (minimal, not particle systems):**
   - Bullet impact: small yellow flash sprite (4x4 pixels, fades in 0.1s)
   - Melee hit: white impact lines (simple graphic, not particles)
   - Muzzle flash: small orange/yellow flash at gun barrel (fades in 0.1s)

3. **Performance Requirements:**
   - 60 FPS maintained with 8 players fighting
   - Effects pooled/reused (not created/destroyed per hit)

**Technical Notes:**
- Health bar: Phaser Graphics object, rectangle drawn above player each frame
- Hit effects: Simple sprites with tween alpha fade
- Implementation: this.add.sprite(x, y, 'impact_flash').setAlpha(1).tween({alpha: 0, duration: 100, onComplete: destroy})
- Tests: Browser acceptance tests for visibility and performance, >90% coverage

**Scope Boundaries:**
- NO particle systems (deferred to Story 9.1)
- NO screen shake or camera effects (deferred to Story 9.1)
- NO advanced animations (deferred to Story 9.1)
- YES health bars and minimal hit feedback
- YES basic visual feedback that makes combat readable

**Why Split from 3.7A:**
- Smaller stories improve agent success rate
- 3.7A focuses on asset integration
- 3.7B focuses on UI systems
- Combined: 2 days total, more manageable

**Prerequisites:** Story 3.7A (Character & Weapon Sprites)

title: Match end leaderboard shows 0 kills and 0 XP for all players
description:
## Summary
When the match ends and the Final Rankings modal appears:
- All players show 0 kills and 0 deaths
- XP breakdown shows correct base XP (50) but Kills multiplier shows 0
- This happens even when players got kills during the match

From screenshot: Both players show Kills: 0, Deaths: 0 in leaderboard despite actual gameplay.

## Root Cause Analysis
The issue is likely in how `finalScores` data is passed from server to client:
1. Server broadcasts `match:ended` with `finalScores` (see `broadcast_helper.go:202-225`)
2. Client receives in `GameSceneEventHandlers.ts:351-373`
3. Data is passed to `window.onMatchEnd()` which triggers React `MatchEndScreen`

Need to investigate:
- Is server correctly tracking kills/deaths during match?
- Is `finalScores` populated correctly at match end?
- Is the data transformation between schema types correct (line 369)?

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Match end leaderboard displays accurate kill counts
- [ ] Match end leaderboard displays accurate death counts
- [ ] XP earned section shows correct kills multiplier
- [ ] Integration test verifies kill tracking through match lifecycle

## Technical Notes
Files to investigate:
- `stick-rumble-server/internal/network/broadcast_helper.go` - broadcastMatchEnded()
- `stick-rumble-server/internal/game/match.go` - kill/death tracking
- `stick-rumble-client/src/game/scenes/GameSceneEventHandlers.ts` - match:ended handler
- `stick-rumble-client/src/ui/MatchEndScreen.tsx` - leaderboard rendering

title: Optimize slow server tests by injecting time dependencies
description:
## Problem

Server tests take ~33 seconds to run due to real-time delays in tests. This slows down development feedback loops and CI pipelines.

## Root Cause Analysis

Tests use `time.Sleep` with actual game timing constants instead of mocked/injectable time:

### Major time sinks identified:
- `gameserver_tick_test.go:216`: `time.Sleep(5 * time.Second)` - health regen delay
- `gameserver_tick_test.go:296`: `time.Sleep(5500 * time.Millisecond)` - health regen after respawn  
- `gameserver_tick_test.go:277`: `time.Sleep(3500 * time.Millisecond)` - respawn timing
- `player_test.go:873`: `time.Sleep(3 * time.Second)` - respawn delay
- `gameserver_shooting_test.go`: Two 1700ms sleeps for reload cooldowns
- 50+ smaller sleeps (50-100ms each) for async operations

### Slow test breakdown:
- `TestGameServerHealthRegenerationAfterRespawn`: 9.00s
- `TestGameServerHealthRegeneration`: 6.10s
- `TestGameServerRespawn_WeaponStateReset`: 3.10s
- `TestGameServerReloadCompleteCallback`: 1.70s
- `TestGameServerReloadCompleteCallback_NoCallback`: 1.70s
- `TestGameServerPhysicsIntegration`: 1.00s

## Proposed Solutions

1. **Inject a clock interface** - Create a `Clock` interface with `Now()` and `Sleep()` methods. Use real clock in production, fake clock in tests that can be advanced instantly.

2. **Use test-specific timing constants** - Allow tests to override `RespawnDelay`, `HealthRegenDelay`, `ReloadTime` etc. with shorter values.

3. **Replace sleeps with event channels** - Instead of sleeping arbitrary durations, wait for specific events/conditions to occur.

4. **Tag slow tests for optional exclusion** - Use `//go:build slow` build tags so developers can skip slow tests during rapid iteration.

## Expected Outcome

Reduce server test runtime from ~33s to <5s while maintaining test coverage and reliability.

## Files to Modify

- `internal/game/gameserver.go` - Add clock injection
- `internal/game/player.go` - Add clock injection for respawn/regen timing
- `internal/game/weapon.go` - Add clock injection for reload timing
- All test files using `time.Sleep`

title: Client-side fire rate cooldown doesn't match automatic weapons (Uzi/AK47)
description:
The ShootingManager uses a hardcoded fireCooldownMs based on WEAPON.PISTOL_FIRE_RATE (333ms), which is too slow for automatic weapons like Uzi (should be 166ms) and AK47 (should be 200ms). This causes the client to artificially throttle automatic fire below the server's allowed rate.

Impact: Automatic weapons fire slower than intended when holding mouse button.

Root cause: fireCooldownMs is set once in constructor and never updated when weapon changes.

Solution: Either:
1. Update fireCooldownMs when weapon changes (requires fire rate in weapon:state message from server)
2. Remove client-side cooldown check and rely purely on server enforcement
3. Use weaponType to look up fire rates from a client-side config

Found during code review of issue 0hv (automatic weapons hold-to-fire feature).
notes:
## Pattern Analysis

This bug is part of a recurring dual-source-of-truth pattern:

### Pattern: Config Sync Issues
Three open issues share this pattern:
- **njr** (this): Client hardcoded PISTOL_FIRE_RATE vs per-weapon fire rates
- **wzq**: weapon-configs.json vs hardcoded WeaponConfig fallback
- **6s2**: Match.PlayerKills vs PlayerState.Kills

### Root Cause
ShootingManager constructor sets fireCooldownMs once from WEAPON.PISTOL_FIRE_RATE (333ms).
When player picks up Uzi (100ms between shots) or AK47 (166ms), the cooldown is never updated.

### Recommended Fix
Use weaponConfig lookup instead of hardcoded constant:
```typescript
// In ShootingManager or on weapon pickup
const config = getWeaponConfigSync(weaponType);
this.fireCooldownMs = 1000 / config.fireRate;
```

### Related Issues
- stick-rumble-wzq: Same need for config lookup (projectile visuals)
- stick-rumble-6s2: Same dual-source pattern (kill tracking)
- stick-rumble-0hv: Hold-to-fire feature that exposed this bug

title: Story 3.5: Implement Sprint Mechanic
description:
Implement sprint mechanic for faster repositioning and retreat.

**SCOPE: Full-stack implementation (client + server)**

**Acceptance Criteria:**

1. **Sprint Activation (Shift key):**
   - Hold Shift while moving with WASD
   - Speed increases from 200 px/s to 300 px/s (1.5x multiplier)
   - Releasing Shift returns to normal speed instantly

2. **No Stamina System:**
   - Can sprint indefinitely (no stamina limit for MVP)
   - Simple mechanic, no resource management

3. **Accuracy Penalty:**
   - Bullet spread increases by 50% while sprinting
   - Multiply spread by 1.5 when isSprinting === true

4. **Audio Cues:**
   - Footsteps +30% louder while sprinting
   - Audio cue for enemies to track sprinting players

5. **Visual Indicator:**
   - Subtle motion blur or speed lines effect
   - Camera FOV increases slightly (zoom out effect)

6. **No Action Restrictions:**
   - Sprinting does NOT prevent shooting, reloading, or aiming
   - Full combat capability while sprinting (with accuracy penalty)

**SERVER Requirements:**
- Track sprint state: {isSprinting: bool}
- Sprint speed validation: 300 px/s (vs normal 200 px/s)
- Prevent speed hacks (cannot sprint + move slower)
- Apply accuracy penalty multiplier (1.5x spread) to shots while sprinting
- Footstep volume modifier: +30% louder while sprinting
- WebSocket messages: input:state includes sprint flag

**CLIENT Requirements:**
- Shift key input handling for sprint toggle
- Speed lines or motion blur effect while sprinting
- Camera FOV adjustment (slight zoom out)
- Louder footstep audio while sprinting (+30%)
- Crosshair spread indicator increases while sprinting
- Visual feedback for accuracy penalty
- WebSocket integration for sprint input state
- Unit tests for client-side sprint code (>90% coverage)

**Technical Notes:**
- Sprint speed: 300 px/s (vs normal 200 px/s)
- Server validates sprint input (cannot sprint + move slower, prevents speed hacks)
- Footstep volume: +30% louder while sprinting

**Prerequisites:** Story 3.4 (Manual Reload)

title: Part 1: Enhanced Phaser Mocks and Scene Lifecycle Unit Tests
description:
## Summary
Agents are shipping code that passes 90%+ test coverage but fails in the actual browser. Human playtesting is catching bugs that automated tests should catch. This is a critical infrastructure issue blocking reliable AI-assisted development.

## Bugs That Slipped Through Current Tests
1. **stick-rumble-at3**: Player sprite duplication - PR #39 claimed to fix but still broken
2. **stick-rumble-o5y**: Melee swing animations not rendering - PR #40 claimed to add but not working
3. **stick-rumble-ela**: Original duplication bug incorrectly marked as fixed

## Root Cause Analysis

### Current Test Infrastructure
| Test Type | Framework | Coverage | Catches Rendering Bugs? |
|-----------|-----------|----------|-------------------------|
| Unit Tests | Vitest | 90%+ statements | ‚ùå No - mocks too simple |
| Integration Tests | Vitest + real server | WebSocket flows | ‚ùå No - no rendering |
| Visual Tests | Playwright | Only 2 UI components | ‚ùå No - no game entities |

### Why Bugs Pass Tests But Fail in Browser

#### 1. Player Duplication Bug (at3/ela)
Unit tests never simulate scene restart lifecycle:
```typescript
// Unit test: Simple isolated scenario
const mockScene = createMockScene();
const manager = new PlayerManager(mockScene);
manager.updatePlayers(players);

// Real browser: Complex lifecycle NOT TESTED
GameScene.create() ‚Üí PlayerManager created
GameScene.update() ‚Üí updatePlayers() called 20Hz
match:ended event ‚Üí cleanup needed
scene.restart() ‚Üí new GameScene.create() ‚Üí new PlayerManager\!
// Unit test never simulates this restart + cleanup
```

#### 2. Melee Animation Bug (o5y/hcf)
Tests verify method calls but not actual rendering:
```typescript
// MeleeWeapon.test.ts - All tests pass but bug exists
it('should render 90-degree swing arc for Bat', () => {
  const graphics = scene.add.graphics();
  weapon.showSwingAnimation(0);
  expect(graphics.arc).toHaveBeenCalled();  // ‚úÖ Passes - arc() was called
  // ‚ùå NOT TESTED: Whether anything was actually drawn on screen
});
```

### Critical Test Gaps

| Gap | Impact |
|-----|--------|
| Phaser mock missing add.graphics(), sprite visibility tracking | Animations 'pass' but don't render |
| No scene lifecycle tests | Restart bugs slip through |
| Visual tests excluded from npm test | CI doesn't catch rendering regressions |
| No game entity visual tests | Only health-bar and kill-feed tested |

### Phaser Mock Analysis (tests/__mocks__/phaser.ts - 59 lines)

**What's Mocked:**
```typescript
class MockScene {
  add = {
    text: vi.fn(),    // Only 2 methods mocked
    circle: vi.fn(),
  };
}
```

**What's MISSING:**
- ‚ùå add.graphics() - No Graphics object mock (critical for MeleeWeapon)
- ‚ùå add.rectangle() - Not in main Phaser mock
- ‚ùå Sprite visibility, position, opacity, tint tracking
- ‚ùå Game loop state tracking
- ‚ùå Scene lifecycle hooks (create, update, shutdown)

### Test Configuration Issue
```typescript
// vitest.config.ts
exclude: [
  '**/*.integration.test.ts',
  '**/tests/visual/**',  // ‚Üê Visual tests excluded from main test run\!
],
```
Impact: `npm test` (main CI command) doesn't run visual regression tests.

## Acceptance Criteria

### Phase 1: Playwright Visual Tests for Game Entities
- [ ] Add visual test for player sprites (verify no duplication after match restart)
- [ ] Add visual test for melee swing animations (Bat brown arc visible, Katana silver arc visible)
- [ ] Add visual test for scene cleanup (no zombie sprites after restart)
- [ ] Create test harness HTML page for game entity testing (similar to /ui-test.html pattern)
- [ ] Visual tests run in CI pipeline

### Phase 2: Scene Lifecycle Unit Tests
- [ ] Test PlayerManager destruction + recreation cycle
- [ ] Test complete scene restart scenario (create ‚Üí destroy ‚Üí create)
- [ ] Verify no zombie objects remain after cleanup
- [ ] Test sprite count matches player count at all times
- [ ] Test multiple consecutive match restarts

### Phase 3: Enhanced Phaser Mocks
- [ ] Add add.graphics() mock with state tracking (visible, destroyed, methods called)
- [ ] Add add.rectangle() mock with position/visibility tracking
- [ ] Add sprite creation/destruction counter
- [ ] Track graphics visibility state throughout animation lifecycle
- [ ] Add scene lifecycle simulation (create, update, shutdown hooks)

### Phase 4: CI Integration
- [ ] Visual tests included in CI pipeline (not excluded)
- [ ] Test report shows rendering validation results
- [ ] Failed visual tests block PR merge
- [ ] Screenshot diffs attached to failed test reports

## Technical Notes

### Existing Visual Test Pattern (to extend)
```typescript
// tests/visual/health-bar.spec.ts - 105 lines
// Uses custom page /ui-test.html with exposed global functions
await page.evaluate(() => {
  (window as any).setHealthBarState(100, 100, false);
});
await expect(page.locator('.health-bar')).toHaveScreenshot();
```

### Proposed Game Entity Test Harness
Create /ui-test-entities.html exposing:
- window.spawnPlayer(id, x, y, color)
- window.removePlayer(id)
- window.getPlayerCount()
- window.triggerMeleeSwing(weaponType, angle)
- window.restartScene()
- window.getActiveSprites()

### Files to Modify/Create
- stick-rumble-client/tests/__mocks__/phaser.ts - Expand mock
- stick-rumble-client/tests/visual/player-sprites.spec.ts - NEW
- stick-rumble-client/tests/visual/melee-animation.spec.ts - NEW
- stick-rumble-client/tests/visual/scene-lifecycle.spec.ts - NEW
- stick-rumble-client/public/ui-test-entities.html - NEW test harness
- stick-rumble-client/src/game/entities/PlayerManager.test.ts - Add lifecycle tests
- stick-rumble-client/vitest.config.ts - Include visual tests in CI
- .github/workflows/* - Add visual test step

### Test File Locations Reference
- Unit Tests: src/game/entities/*.test.ts
- Integration Tests: src/game/network/*.integration.test.ts
- Visual Tests: tests/visual/*.spec.ts
- Mocks: tests/__mocks__/phaser.ts
- Setup: tests/setup.ts
- Playwright Config: playwright.config.ts

## Success Metrics
- Agents can run tests that catch rendering bugs BEFORE human playtesting
- No more 'fix merged but bug still exists' scenarios
- Visual regression tests catch sprite duplication
- Animation tests verify actual rendering, not just method calls
- Scene lifecycle tests catch cleanup failures

## Related Issues
- stick-rumble-at3: Player sprite duplication (would be caught by Phase 1)
- stick-rumble-o5y: Melee animation not working (would be caught by Phase 1)
- stick-rumble-ela: Original duplication bug (would be caught by Phase 2)

title: Tech Debt: GameSimulation Class (Simulation Phase 2)
description:
Create pure logic GameSimulation class for headless client testing.

**Research Reference:** research/2026-01-12-headless-game-testing-strategies.md

**Acceptance Criteria:**

1. Create GameSimulation class with pure logic (no Phaser):
   - addPlayer(id, position): void
   - updateInput(playerId, input): void
   - tick(deltaMs): void
   - getPlayerState(id): PlayerState
   - getAllPlayers(): PlayerState[]

2. Extract physics from PlayerManager into testable functions:
   - updatePlayerPhysics(player, dt): pure math
   - checkCollisions(): pure geometry
   - Reuse existing physics.ts patterns from server

3. Add event callbacks for assertions:
   - onHit(callback): register hit event listener
   - onDeath(callback): register death event listener
   - onWeaponPickup(callback): register pickup listener

4. Create simulateTicks() helper (mirror server pattern):
   - Run N ticks instantly with ManualClock
   - Pattern from gameserver_tick_test.go:12-32

5. Unit tests with >90% coverage:
   - Player movement in all directions
   - Projectile-player collision detection
   - Weapon cooldowns and reload

**Technical Notes:**
- GameSimulation is the client equivalent of GameServer
- No Phaser imports - pure TypeScript/math
- Enables 1000s of game ticks to run in milliseconds

title: Refactor network package tests for better quality and maintainability
description:
The network package tests achieve >90% coverage but have quality issues:

## Issues to Fix
1. Poor test file organization - 5 files with names like 'coverage_boost_test.go' that don't describe what they test
2. Weak assertions - heavy use of assert.NotPanics() without verifying actual behavior
3. Test duplication - same functions tested in multiple files
4. Integration tests don't verify message delivery
5. Over-reliance on time.Sleep() instead of proper synchronization

## Recommended Approach
1. Consolidate 5 test files into 2-3 well-organized files by feature area
2. Strengthen assertions to verify actual behavior, not just 'no panic'
3. Remove duplicate tests, keep best version of each
4. Update integration tests to read and validate WebSocket messages
5. Replace time.Sleep with proper synchronization primitives

## Benefits
- More maintainable test suite
- Tests verify correctness, not just coverage
- Easier to understand what each test validates
- Reduces test execution time

- Original coverage task: stick-rumble-4gv
- Test files: internal/network/*_test.go

title: Story 3.4: Implement Manual Reload Mechanic
description:
Implement manual reload mechanic for tactical ammo management.

**SCOPE: Full-stack implementation (client + server)**

**Acceptance Criteria:**

1. **Manual Reload (R key):**
   - Press R to start reload animation
   - During reload: cannot shoot (clicking does nothing)
   - Reload progress bar appears on HUD (fills over reload duration)
   - After completion: magazine refills to max capacity

2. **Reload Times Per Weapon:**
   - Uzi: 1.5 seconds
   - AK47: 2.0 seconds
   - Shotgun: 2.5 seconds

3. **Cancel & Auto-Reload:**
   - Cancel reload by switching weapons (lose progress)
   - Auto-reload triggers when shooting with empty magazine
   - Empty indicator: "RELOAD!" flashes on screen in red

4. **Movement During Reload:**
   - Can move, sprint, and dodge while reloading (not stunned)
   - Reload does NOT cancel on movement

**SERVER Requirements:**
- Track reload state: {isReloading: bool, reloadStartTime: timestamp}
- Reload progress calculation: (now - reloadStartTime) / reloadDuration
- Validate reload completion before allowing shots
- Handle cancel triggers: weapon switch, weapon pickup
- Auto-reload trigger: attempt to shoot with ammo === 0
- WebSocket messages: reload:start, reload:complete, reload:cancel

**CLIENT Requirements:**
- R key input handling to trigger reload
- Reload progress bar UI on HUD (fills over reload duration)
- "RELOAD!" flashing red indicator when magazine empty
- Circular reload indicator around crosshair
- Reload sound effects (unique per weapon type)
- Character animation: lowers weapon, reload gesture, raises weapon
- Block shoot input during reload (visual feedback only, server validates)
- WebSocket integration for reload state sync
- Unit tests for client-side reload code (>90% coverage)

**Technical Notes:**
- Server is authoritative for reload state
- Client shows progress based on server timestamps
- Cancel triggers: weapon switch, weapon pickup
- Auto-reload trigger: attempt to shoot with ammo === 0

title: Story 3.3: Implement Ranged Weapons (Uzi, AK47, Shotgun)
description:
Implement three ranged weapons with distinct characteristics for varied playstyles.

**SCOPE: Full-stack implementation (client + server)**

**Acceptance Criteria:**

1. **Uzi (SMG):**
   - 8 damage per bullet, 10 rounds/second (full-auto, hold to fire)
   - 600px max range, 30-round magazine, 1.5s reload
   - Recoil: aim angle climbs 2¬∞ per shot, recovers over 0.5s
   - Spread: +/-5¬∞ while moving

2. **AK47 (Rifle):**
   - 20 damage per bullet, 6 rounds/second (semi-auto, hold for continuous)
   - 800px max range, 30-round magazine, 2.0s reload
   - Balanced recoil: horizontal + vertical, +/-3¬∞ pattern
   - Accurate while stationary, spread while moving

3. **Shotgun:**
   - 8 pellets per shot, 7.5 damage each (60 total if all hit)
   - 300px max range, 15¬∞ cone spread
   - 1 shot/second, 6-round magazine, 2.5s reload
   - Devastating close range, weak at distance (spread too wide)

4. **CRITICAL - Damage Falloff (all ranged weapons):**
   ```
   if (distance > maxRange * 0.5) {
     damageFalloff = 1.0 - ((distance - maxRange * 0.5) / (maxRange * 0.5))
     actualDamage = baseDamage * damageFalloff
   }
   ```
   Example: AK47 at 400px = 20 dmg, 600px = 10 dmg, 800px = 0 dmg

- Weapon stats validation and storage

- Fire rate validation to prevent macros/exploits

**CLIENT Requirements:**
- Weapon entities in src/game/entities/ for each weapon type

title: Fix failing broadcast tests exposed by game server initialization
description:
After starting the game server in tests (stick-rumble-72z), several broadcast tests are now failing due to race conditions and timing issues:

FAILING TESTS:
- TestBroadcastProjectileSpawn: projectileId field is nil
- TestBroadcastPlayerDamaged: playerId nil, health not reduced  
- TestBroadcastPlayerDeath: message not received within 2s timeout
- TestBroadcastKillCredit: message not received within 2s timeout
- TestBroadcastWeaponPickup: respawnTime field nil
- TestBroadcastMatchTimer: assertion failure

ROOT CAUSE:
Tests call handler methods directly (ts.handler.onHit, ts.handler.sendWeaponState, etc.) to trigger message broadcasts. However, connections close (via defer conn.Close()) before the game server's broadcast loop can send the messages. This creates race conditions.

RECOMMENDED FIX:
1. Add small delays (100-200ms) after triggering events to allow broadcast loop to send messages
2. OR modify tests to trigger events through normal game flow (input messages) instead of direct handler calls
3. Ensure connections stay open long enough to receive all expected messages

These are test quality issues, not production bugs. The game server works correctly - the tests just need better synchronization.
close_reason: Fixed in PR #24 - Broadcast tests refactored with proper synchronization, all tests now pass

title: Fix intermittent test failures in network package (race condition)

comments.author: mtomcal
comments.text: Race condition identified: Multiple tests calling NewWebSocketHandler() causes concurrent schema loading with excessive logging. Every test loads 41 schemas (7 client-to-server + 34 server-to-client) independently. When tests run in parallel, this creates log spam and race conditions. Solution: Implement singleton pattern for SchemaLoader using sync.Once to ensure schemas load only once per test run.

comments.author: mtomcal
comments.text:
=== PHASE 1: Investigation Complete ===

Current state:
- Schema loader singleton pattern already implemented with sync.Once
- GetClientToServerSchemaLoader() and GetServerToClientSchemaLoader() use sync.Once 
- resetSchemaLoaderSingletons() exists for testing
- Global handler (globalHandler) created at package init time (line 97)

Race condition analysis:
1. Multiple tests create handlers via NewWebSocketHandler() or use global HandleWebSocket
2. Each handler creation calls Get*SchemaLoader() which loads schemas once
3. The singleton pattern prevents duplicate loading BUT the global handler loads schemas at package init
4. When tests run in parallel with -race, there may be contention on schema loading logs
5. The global handler shares state across tests using HandleWebSocket directly

Key issues identified:
- Global handler (line 97) creates singleton loaders at package initialization
- Some tests use globalHandler (via HandleWebSocket function), others create new handlers
- Tests don't consistently reset singletons between runs
- Potential log interleaving during parallel test execution

=== PHASE 2: Implementation Plan ===

Plan:
1. Add TestMain to reset singletons before each test package run
2. Ensure tests that use global HandleWebSocket get isolated handler instances
3. Add test to verify singleton behavior under parallel load with race detector
4. Run extensive race detection tests to verify fix
5. Ensure >90% coverage maintained

title: Optimize slow server tests by injecting time dependencies
description:
## Problem

Server tests take ~33 seconds to run due to real-time delays in tests. This slows down development feedback loops and CI pipelines.

## Root Cause Analysis

Tests use `time.Sleep` with actual game timing constants instead of mocked/injectable time:

### Major time sinks identified:
- `gameserver_tick_test.go:216`: `time.Sleep(5 * time.Second)` - health regen delay
- `gameserver_tick_test.go:296`: `time.Sleep(5500 * time.Millisecond)` - health regen after respawn  
- `gameserver_tick_test.go:277`: `time.Sleep(3500 * time.Millisecond)` - respawn timing
- `player_test.go:873`: `time.Sleep(3 * time.Second)` - respawn delay
- `gameserver_shooting_test.go`: Two 1700ms sleeps for reload cooldowns
- 50+ smaller sleeps (50-100ms each) for async operations

### Slow test breakdown:
- `TestGameServerHealthRegenerationAfterRespawn`: 9.00s
- `TestGameServerHealthRegeneration`: 6.10s
- `TestGameServerRespawn_WeaponStateReset`: 3.10s
- `TestGameServerReloadCompleteCallback`: 1.70s
- `TestGameServerReloadCompleteCallback_NoCallback`: 1.70s
- `TestGameServerPhysicsIntegration`: 1.00s

## Proposed Solutions

1. **Inject a clock interface** - Create a `Clock` interface with `Now()` and `Sleep()` methods. Use real clock in production, fake clock in tests that can be advanced instantly.

2. **Use test-specific timing constants** - Allow tests to override `RespawnDelay`, `HealthRegenDelay`, `ReloadTime` etc. with shorter values.

3. **Replace sleeps with event channels** - Instead of sleeping arbitrary durations, wait for specific events/conditions to occur.

4. **Tag slow tests for optional exclusion** - Use `//go:build slow` build tags so developers can skip slow tests during rapid iteration.

## Expected Outcome

Reduce server test runtime from ~33s to <5s while maintaining test coverage and reliability.

## Files to Modify

- `internal/game/gameserver.go` - Add clock injection
- `internal/game/player.go` - Add clock injection for respawn/regen timing
- `internal/game/weapon.go` - Add clock injection for reload timing
- All test files using `time.Sleep`

title: Story 3.5: Implement Sprint Mechanic
description:
Implement sprint mechanic for faster repositioning and retreat.

**SCOPE: Full-stack implementation (client + server)**

**Acceptance Criteria:**

1. **Sprint Activation (Shift key):**
   - Hold Shift while moving with WASD
   - Speed increases from 200 px/s to 300 px/s (1.5x multiplier)
   - Releasing Shift returns to normal speed instantly

2. **No Stamina System:**
   - Can sprint indefinitely (no stamina limit for MVP)
   - Simple mechanic, no resource management

3. **Accuracy Penalty:**
   - Bullet spread increases by 50% while sprinting
   - Multiply spread by 1.5 when isSprinting === true

4. **Audio Cues:**
   - Footsteps +30% louder while sprinting
   - Audio cue for enemies to track sprinting players

5. **Visual Indicator:**
   - Subtle motion blur or speed lines effect
   - Camera FOV increases slightly (zoom out effect)

6. **No Action Restrictions:**
   - Sprinting does NOT prevent shooting, reloading, or aiming
   - Full combat capability while sprinting (with accuracy penalty)

**SERVER Requirements:**
- Track sprint state: {isSprinting: bool}
- Sprint speed validation: 300 px/s (vs normal 200 px/s)
- Prevent speed hacks (cannot sprint + move slower)
- Apply accuracy penalty multiplier (1.5x spread) to shots while sprinting
- Footstep volume modifier: +30% louder while sprinting
- WebSocket messages: input:state includes sprint flag

**CLIENT Requirements:**
- Shift key input handling for sprint toggle
- Speed lines or motion blur effect while sprinting
- Camera FOV adjustment (slight zoom out)
- Louder footstep audio while sprinting (+30%)
- Crosshair spread indicator increases while sprinting
- Visual feedback for accuracy penalty
- WebSocket integration for sprint input state
- Unit tests for client-side sprint code (>90% coverage)

**Technical Notes:**
- Sprint speed: 300 px/s (vs normal 200 px/s)
- Server validates sprint input (cannot sprint + move slower, prevents speed hacks)
- Footstep volume: +30% louder while sprinting

**Prerequisites:** Story 3.4 (Manual Reload)

title: Fix weapon-configs.json missing projectile visuals and add config sync tests
description:
## Problem
The weapon-configs.json file is missing the `projectile` sub-object within `visuals` for each weapon. This causes all weapons to fall back to default yellow projectiles (0xffff00) instead of using the distinct colors/sizes defined in the hardcoded fallback.

## Root Cause
Commit 376700b ("Add distinct firing patterns and visual character to automatic weapons") only updated the hardcoded fallback in `getHardcodedWeaponConfigs()` but did NOT update `weapon-configs.json`. Since the JSON file loads successfully, the hardcoded fallback is never used, and all projectiles render identically.

## Current Behavior
- All weapons fire yellow projectiles with same size
- Uzi, AK47, Pistol, Shotgun are visually indistinguishable

## Expected Behavior
- Pistol: Yellow bullets (4px), yellow tracer (2px)
- Uzi: Orange bullets (3px), orange tracer (1.5px) 
- AK47: Gold bullets (5px), gold tracer (2.5px)
- Shotgun: Orange-red bullets (6px), orange-red tracer (3px)

## Tasks

### A) Fix the Bug
1. Update `stick-rumble-client/public/weapon-configs.json` to include `projectile` object within `visuals` for each weapon
2. Update `weapon-configs.json` at project root (if used)
3. Verify visuals render correctly in-game

### B) Add Testing to Prevent Recurrence

#### Test 1: Config File vs Hardcoded Parity
Add integration test that verifies weapon-configs.json has the same structure as hardcoded fallback:
- All fields present in hardcoded must exist in JSON
- Fail if JSON is missing any nested properties

#### Test 2: Schema Validation Test  
Add test that validates weapon-configs.json against WeaponConfig TypeScript interface:
- Use TypeBox schema or manual validation
- Run at test time to catch schema drift

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] weapon-configs.json includes projectile visuals for all ranged weapons
- [ ] Uzi fires orange 3px projectiles (not yellow)
- [ ] AK47 fires gold 5px projectiles (not yellow)
- [ ] Integration test exists verifying JSON/hardcoded parity
- [ ] Schema validation test exists for weapon-configs.json
- [ ] All tests pass
- [ ] >90% coverage maintained
notes:
## Pattern Analysis

This bug shares a common pattern with several other open issues:

### Pattern: Dual Source of Truth / Data Sync Issues
- **wzq** (this issue): weapon-configs.json vs hardcoded fallback
- **6s2**: Match.PlayerKills vs PlayerState.Kills  
- **njr**: Client hardcoded fire rate vs server weapon config

All three have the same root cause: two places storing/tracking the same data that can get out of sync.

### Pattern: Unit Tests Pass But Bug Exists
- Tests verify individual components in isolation
- No integration test verifies the actual data flow end-to-end
- Bug only appears in real runtime when actual config file is loaded

### Recommended Fix Approach
1. Fix the immediate bug (update JSON file)
2. Add parity test that fails if JSON differs from hardcoded
3. Consider: Should we have ONE source of truth instead of two?

### Related Issues
- stick-rumble-6s2: Same dual-source pattern for kill tracking
- stick-rumble-njr: Same pattern for fire rate config
- stick-rumble-48z: Visual tests would catch render differences

title: Story 3.7A: Character & Weapon Sprites
description:
Create character and weapon sprites for visual polish and weapon identification.

**Acceptance Criteria:**

1. **Stick Figure Character:**
   - 16x32 pixel sprite (head, body, limbs clearly visible)
   - 4-frame walk animation (8-12 FPS, cycles smoothly)
   - Distinct idle pose vs moving pose
   - Color customization working (black default, other colors unlocked)

2. **Weapon Sprites (all 6 weapons):**
   - Pistol: small handgun, 8x8 pixels, silver/gray
   - Bat: wooden bat, 16x4 pixels, brown
   - Katana: sleek blade, 20x4 pixels, silver with black handle
   - Uzi: compact SMG, 12x8 pixels, black/gray
   - AK47: rifle shape, 20x8 pixels, wood/metal colors
   - Shotgun: pump-action, 18x8 pixels, dark gray/brown

3. **Weapon Rendering:**
   - Weapons rotate correctly with aim angle
   - Anchor point at weapon handle
   - Weapons visible when held by other players (rendered at player position + aim angle)

4. **Art Sourcing:**
   - Use free assets from Kenney.nl (Micro Roguelike, Top-Down Shooter packs)
   - Or create simple pixel art (16x16 or smaller)

**Technical Notes:**
- Client assets: public/assets/sprites/character.png, weapons/*.png
- Phaser loading: this.load.spritesheet('player', 'assets/sprites/character.png', {frameWidth: 16, frameHeight: 32})
- Animation: this.anims.create({key: 'walk', frames: generateFrameNumbers('player', {start: 0, end: 3}), frameRate: 10, repeat: -1})
- Weapon: this.add.sprite(x, y, 'weapon_pistol').setRotation(aimAngle)
- Quality: Readable at 1920x1080, weapons visually distinct, <500KB total
- Tests: Mock sprite paths, verify rendering methods called, >90% coverage

**Scope Boundaries:**
- NO particle systems (deferred to Story 9.1)
- NO advanced animations (idle breathing, death animations, ragdolls)
- YES basic sprites that make game shareable and clear

**Prerequisites:** Story 3.6 (Dodge Roll)
